Legal_Issue: Can points be awarded for years of study not contributing to the highest educational credential under section 78?
Governing_Law: Section 78(3) of Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review before the Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Kabir completed 18 years of study but only 16 were required for his Master’s degree; second Master’s and diploma not in progression of highest credential
Decision_Outcome: No reviewable error by the officer
Legal_Rule: Only the highest educational credential counts; no cumulative points for multiple credentials
Grounds_for_Claim: Request for additional points based on secondary qualifications
Judicial_Review_Outcome: Application dismissed, question certified due to differing judicial views
Review_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to administrative decisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Duration and relevance of Kabir's studies to his highest credential
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Challenged denial of points for additional qualifications
Legal_Rule_Source: Section 78(3) of Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Defendant_Response: Officer applied regulation correctly, no error
Remedy_Requested: Review of points allocation for permanent residence application
Remedy_Sought: Reassessment of application with additional points
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 78(3) of Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Applicable_Process: Permanent residence application under economic class
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Certification of question for further clarification
Governing_Rule: Section 78(3) IRPR – single highest credential rule
